string.text: Standard 12-caliber round filled with 6mm shot. Highly lethal at close range. Only suitable for use with smoothbore weapons.
This heavy 12 caliber slug round is normally used for hunting big game, but is also good for other purposes. Instead of piercing, this hefty slug simply crushes through armor.
A full metal jacket round with a steel penetrator and a lead core under a metal jacket. Provides good stopping power but is ineffective against body armor.

This round contains a bullet with enhanced stopping power, while its European +P+ designation indicates “overpressure ammunition” with a 30% increase in muzzle velocity. Ineffective against body armor.

This basic 9x19 caliber round with a jacketed bullet has good characteristics while being simple to produce. The round is popular due to the fact that international conventions prohibit the use of expanding ammunition in combat. Ineffective against body armor.

This 9x19 caliber jacketed hollow point bullet with an expanding hollow provides high stopping power and low ricochet propensity. Used by police and for self-defense. Ineffective against body armor due to its low penetration potential.

A Belgian small-caliber, high-velocity cartridge, designed for maximum velocity and penetration in personal defense weapons. It is in use with various police and special forces units around the world. Marginally effective against body armor.

A variant of the Belgian 5.7x28mm cartridge (index SS190) that has even higher armor penetration due to the hardedned steel core. Restricted to military and law enforcement use. Effective against body armor.
A very large and powerful pistol cartridge exported by IMI under the title “Samson Ultra.” Designed for use in the Desert Eagle pistol. Ineffective against body armor.

An American-made magnum cartridge that was made to penetrate car doors and armor vests used by gangsters in the 1930s. Even today it is known as a powerful cartridge for self-defense and hunting medium game. Ineffective against body armor.

The .45 caliber full metal jacket round has enjoyed popularity for more than a hundred years thanks to its high stopping power. The bullet in this round is relatively slow but highly accurate. Ineffective against body armor.

This unusual .45 ACP caliber jacketed soft point round features an expanding hollow and a steel core. It is a combination of jacketed expanding soft point and armor piercing bullets, benefiting from the advantages of both and suffering from their downsides.

Soviet 5.45x39 caliber PP round with a steel core, GRAU index 7N10. Provides better accuracy than the 7.62 caliber round thanks to reduced recoil and a 100 meter increase in range. Ineffective against body armor.
Russian 5.45x39 caliber BP enhanced penetration round, GRAU index 7N22. Introduced in 2002, the bullet contains a hard-alloy, armor-piercing penetrator. Effective against body armor.

NATO 5.56x45 caliber cartridge under the designation SS109, developed in the 1980s by Fabrique Nationale to replace the M193 round used since Vietnam. Features a heavier bullet with increased penetration at the cost of stopping power. Marginally effective against body armor.
A common NATO military 5.56x45 caliber armor-piercing round, adopted by the US Army in 2010 as the M855A1. Provides improved armor-piercing capability over the SS109/M855.

The SP-5 is a special-purpose cartridge with a conventional lead core FMJ bullet, GRAU index 7N8. The bullet is lighter than the SP-6 variant, granting it a flatter trajectory and higher accuracy. Marginally effective against body armor.

The PAB-9 cheaper version of the expensive SP-6 cartidge with a stamped steel penetrator, GRAU index 7N12. However, the stamping process led to a drastic decrease in effectiveness, and it was banned from official use. Ineffective against body armor.

The SP-6 is a special-purpose cartridge with an armor-piercing core that protrudes from the casing, GRAU index 7N9. The high-caliber subsonic bullet features hollow, hardened steel, providing excellent stopping power and armor penetration but a steep trajectory. Used by special forces of ex-Soviet countries. Effective against body armor.

A Soviet high-velocity pistol cartridge with a lead core (Type P), GAU index 57-N-132. Based on the German 7.63x25mm Mauser cartridge, its powerful charge allows great penetration capability. Marginally effective against body armor.
A Soviet high-velocity pistol cartridge with a steel core (PS), GAU index 57-N-132S. Its hardened steel core allows even better penetration than the standard FMJ round. Effective against body armor.

A Soviet intermediate cartidge with a steel core (PS), GAU index 57-N-231. Originally designed to be used with the SKS rifle and RPD light machine gun, it is most famously used in the AK series of rifles and remains one of the most popular rifle cartridges in the world. Ineffective against body armor.

A 7.62x39mm cartridge with an improved steel penetrator (BP), GRAU index 7N23. It was developed in 2002 in response to a rise in use of body armor in militaries around the world. Effective against body armor.
An American rifle cartridge with a standard FMJ bullet, index M59. Widely used in the Vietnam War until the adoption of the M16 and 5.56 cartridge. Ineffective against body armor.
An American armor-piercing rifle cartridge, index M61. Uses a hardened steel core painted with a black tip. Effective against body armor.

A Russian rifle cartridge with a steel core (LPS), GAU index 57-N-323S, dating back to the late 19th century. This variant is designed to be used in the PKM general purpose machine gun. Ineffective against body armor.
A Soviet sniper rifle cartridge with a hardened U12A steel core (SNB), GRAU index 7N14. Adopted in 1999 to replace the 7N1 sniper round. Effective against body armor.
A Russian armor-piercing rifle cartridge (BP), GRAU index 7N26. Adopted in 2002 for use in the PKM and other machine guns. Effective against body armor.
A Finnish long-range semi-jacketed sniper cartridge (SP). It is known for accuracy and performance at long range. Effective against body armor.
Energy cells prepared with lethal elements in a Gauss rifle magazine. The energy source is an encapsulated piece of the Flash Artifact.
Homemade energy cells in a Gauss rifle magazine. As a result of a lack of specialized equipment, the batteries are slightly less powerful.
A Russian armor-piercing rifle cartridge (BP), GRAU index 7N26. Adopted in 2002 for use in the PKM and other machine guns. Effective against body armor.
A high explosive 40mm fragmentation warhead for the RPG-7. It is designed to defeat lightly armored vehicles, but can be used against infantry as well.
A defensive hand grenade with a large radius of shrapnel damage. It is recommended to throw it only from behind cover.
An offensive hand grenade with a small radius of shrapnel damage.
A smoke grenade. Creates a smoke screen for cover. Lasts for 10 seconds.
Chemical flare grenade. Designed to illuminate areas during night fights and to dazzle and disorient the enemy. Lasts less than a minute.
A caseless 40mm grenade developed at first for the BG-15 launcher. Most commonly used in the Zone for the GP-25 and RG-6 launchers.
A caseless 40mm grenade developed for Russian grenade launchers. Upon impact it “leaps” into the air, then explodes.
An American 40mm grenade developed for the M203 grenade launcher. Has a kill radius of 5 meters.
An optical sight featuring variable magnification. It is used on hunting rifles and is designed for precise focusing when shooting. The the scope is mounted using special brackets.

A Soviet rifle optic with 4x magnification. It is a copy of the British SUIT optic adapted to be used on rifles using the Soviet side rail. A few differences include the inverted post reticle and built-in range finder markings.
A night vision optic intended for weapons with dovetail mounts.
A Russian collimator sight designed for close quarters and urban combat. It can be used on weapons with the Soviet side rail mount.
An American holographic sight that can be used on weapons with a Weaver/picatinny rail.
A very compact series of civilian red dot sights that have proven reliablity and simplicity.
A Russian red dot tube optic for fast target acquisition at close ranges. It can be used on weapons with a Soviet side rail mount.
An Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight. It provides medium power magnification and immense durability. It can be used on weapons with a Weaver/picatinny rail.
A cheap red dot optic with 2x magnification. Can be used on weapons with a Weaver/picatinny rail.
A Soviet 5.0x fixed magnification scope with range finder markings. It can be used on weapons with a Soviet side rail.
A 2.7x optical scope for urban combat at medium range. Attached to weapons by means of a dovetail mount.
An antiquated Soviet night vision optic with fixed 5.0x magnification. It can be used on weapons with a Soviet side rail.

A 5.0x fixed zoom optical scope with a built-in heat visor used to identify heat sources typical of the human body. Designed for use by special forces. Attached to weapons by means of a dovetail mount.
A British 4.0x magnification optic with a tritium insert that allows it to be use during both day and night. It can be used on weapons with an accessory rail.
An Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight. Has a fixed 1.6x magnification. It can be used on weapons with an accessory rail.
An Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight, Dusk. Designed for close quarters enagements in low light conditions. It can be used on weapons with an accessory rail.
An Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight, Night. The trilux insert allows the optic to be used in environments with little to no light. It can be used on weapons with an accessory rail.
An Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight, Range Finder. Has a trilux insert for low light conditions and a an adjustable magnification. It can be used on weapons with an accessory rail.
A suppressor for 9mm pistols and sub-machine guns.
A suppressor for the Glock and FN FNP.
A suppressor for .45 ACP pistols and sub-machine guns.
A suppressor for the 5.56x45mm AK-102 and 7.62x39mm AK-103 and AK-104.
A suppressor for AK series rifles.
A suppressor for 5.56x45mm weapons, as well as for .45 ACP- pistols and submachine guns.

%c[255,1,255,255]•%c[default] VOG-25, VOG-25P
 
A muzzle loaded, under barrel grenade launcher for AK series rifles. It fires 40mm caseless grenades.

%c[255,1,255,255]•%c[default] M209
 
An M203 grenade launcher modifed to be mounted by Picatinny rail on various rifles. It fires 40mm grenades.

%c[255,1,255,255]•%c[default] M209
 
A grenade launcher designed to be mounted on the German G36 rifle. It fires 40mm grenades.

An automatic carbine in use by various Russian military and police units. The 9x3mm cartridge has superior penetration and power compared to 5.56mm and 5.45x39mm, but the steep trajectory of the subsonic bullet effectively restricts the 9A91 to ranges of about 100 meters.

nOriginally developed to replace the aging AK-74 series of rifles. The unique internal workings of the rifle allow it to burst fire 2 rounds and have them both land at nearly the same spot. However, the complex mechanism and high price led it to being used only by elite forces of the Russian military.

Based on previous AK rifles in internal design and layout, the AEK-971 is also equipped with a recoil-balancing counter-weight mechanism that negates the impusle of the gas piston and bolt carrier, resulting in more controllable automatic fire.

An early assault rifle developed in response to the shortcomings of Soviet infantry weapons during World War II. It has since become one of the most common firearms in the world due to its low price and ease of use with little training.
A variant of the AK-47 featuring a wire folding stock that reduces weight and increases portability. It was designed for use in armored vehicles and by paratroopers.

A replacement for the earlier AKM with a new 5.45x39mm cartridge and improved muzzle break. The new lighter cartridge gives the rifle increased range, accuracy, and reliability over previous AK rifles while allowing soldiers to carry more ammunition.
A modernized variant of the AK-74 rifle with new synthetic furniture, lightened bolt and carrier assembly, modified muzzle break, and a side-folding stock.
A “night” version of the AK-74 with a dovetail mount intended for attaching both powered night vision optics and other various types of sights.

An AK series rifle designed for international export. A carbine variant of the AK-101 rifle that serves as a middle ground in between the full length AK rifles and the compact AKS-74U. It features an accessory rail for optics.
A variant of the AK-74M rifle chambered in the 7.62x39mm cartridge. The plastic furniture is designed to reduce the overall weight of the weapon.
A variant of the AK-104 with applied camouflage for reduced user visibility in addition to a 45 round magazine and an integrated Kobra sight.
A carbine variant of the AK-74M rifle that serves as a middle ground in between the full length AK rifles and the compact AKS-74U.

%c[255,255,255,255]Optics: 
%c[default]EKP-1S-03 Kobra, EKP-8-02 Kobra, 1P29 "Tyulpan", PSO-1
 
%c[255,255,255,255]Attachments: 
%c[default]GP-25, PBS-1 Suppressor
 
A modernized version of the AK-47 with various improvements that include adding a muzzle break, a lighter construction and simpler manufacturing process. It has been used in nearly every war that has occurred since it's creation and exportation by the Soviet Union. It is well known for it's fool-proof operation and unbeatable reliablity.
A variant of the AKM featuring a wire folding stock that reduces weight and increases portability. It was designed for use in armored vehicles and by paratroopers.
A variant of the AK-74 with a triangular side-folding stock designed for use by air assault infantry. The stamped steel stock is much more sturdy than the AKMS’ wire folding stock.

A shortened variant of the AK-74 with a triangle folding stock, modified muzzle break and a shortened operating mechanism resulting in an increased fire rate. Its compact size makes it ideal for special forces, airborne infantry and police who require the form factor of a submachine gun and the power of a rifle in one package.

A modified AKS-74U equipped with a permanently attached EKP-1S-03 Kobra red dot sight, a PBS-4 suppressor, and a 45-round magazine. This particular model was custom-made for a mercenary known as Beast.

An Austrian bullpup assault rifle with an integrated 1.5x fixed magnification optic. In addition to being used as a service rifle, it is also currently in use with many police and special forces teams around the world.

A British bolt-action sniper rifle specially designed for improved performance in very cold conditions. It was developed by Accuracy International and is renowned for accuracy and reliability in adverse conditions.

An American bolt-action sniper rifle that can acheieve sub-MOA accuracy with proper ammunition. Although it carries a hefty price, it has many ergonomic features such as the adjustable buttstock and pistol grip.

The CZ 52 is a semi-automatic pistol developed in the early 1950s for the Czechoslovak military. It was designed by Jan and Jaroslav Kratochvil, both working for Ceska zbrojovka Strakonice. Like the TT-33, it is chambered for 7.62x25mm Tokarev rounds.

One of the original “wonder nine” pistols from the 1970s featuring an all-steel construction and a staggered-column magazine. Its inherently accurate design and ergonomic shape have made it popular in sports shooting.

German battle rifle that has a proven reputation for reliability and ease of manufacturing. It is one of the most exported NATO rifles in the world and is still is use with various militaries. The A3 variant has drum sights, a fixed plastic stock and a plastic hanguard.

An accurized variant of the G3 intended for sniper or designated marksman use. A magnified optic has been fitted using the H&K claw mount and the trigger has been modified for a consistent, crisp pull each and every shot.
A Belgian semi-automatic pistol named after its 5.7x28mm cartridge. The special cartridge allows the pistol to have a large magazine capacity, low recoil and the ability to penetrate body armor.
A Belgian semi-automatic pistol with a polymer frame with a double/single action mechanism. It is fully ambidexterous and has a large magazine capacity compared to other .45 ACP pistols.
A Russian semi-automatic pistol that serves as the standard sidearm for the Russian Military. It is designed to use overpressure armor-piercing cartridges but it can use any 9x19mm cartridge.

A Soviet semi-automatic pistol that served as the main sidearm of the Russian military forces during WWII. The high velocity 7.62x25mm cartridge that gives the pistol excellent penetration against lighter body armor.

A Russian select fire machine pistol designed to replace the aging APS in various Russian paramilitary units. The special slide and barrel mechanism make the pistol much more controllable during automatic fire and keeps the fire rate down to manageable levels.
A Russian semi-automatic pistol designed to defeat light body armor using special armor-piercing PBP 9x19mm cartridges.
An Austrian semi-automatic pistol with a polymer frame and no manual safety. They are very popular due to their reliablility, simplicity and affordability.
A variant of the Glock 17 that is lighter and more compact. They are very popular due to their reliablility, simplicity and affordability.
A Russian semi-automatic shotgun based on the Kalashnikov action. It is popular among civilian shooters and is in service with a few military and police units in Europe and the Middle East.
A custom-built Saiga shotgun, formerly owned by Trapper. Compared to a regular Saiga-12, it was modified to have greater accuracy at the expense of a lower rate of fire.

A Russian squad automatic weapon designed alongside the AK series rifles with a few modifications. It has a longer and heavier barrel that allows the weapon to fire for extended periods of time without overheating or losing accuracy.

A Russian squad automatic weapon introduced along with the AK-74 rifle. Differences between this and the original RPK inlcude the change to the new 5.45x39mm cartridge, redesigned bipod and new 45 round magazines.

An Italian semi-automatic pistol that replaced the M1911 pistol in the United States military. Although it is larger than most other 9x19mm pistols, it is very reliable and has a respectable 15 round magazine capacity.

The M9—the US Army designation for the officially adopted Beretta 92SB—has managed to find its way into the Zone. It’s popular with criminals thanks to a powerful cartridge and its large magazine capacity. You can not generally find the newest model of this weapon in the Zone.
A civilian double-barrel hunting shotgun that has been cut down to a much more compact size. Although its range is severly reduced, it can still pack a punch up close.

An American semi-automatic pistol designed in response to the disappointing stopping power of the revolvers used by the US Army in the early 20th century. Even over 100 years later, the pistol remains popular among civilians, police, and military units for its reliability and simplicity.
An Isreali-American semi-automatic pistol made famous by popular media for its intimidating size and large .50 AE cartridge. It was designed in the United States but manufactured in Israel.
A variant of the Desert Eagle pistol featuring a unique color scheme, a DOCTER red dot sight, and a compensator to reduce recoil.

A relatively new Belgian bullpup assault rifle with a unique ambidexterous design that ejects spent casings from the front of the rifle instead of the rear and an integrated 1.6x fixed magnification optic. It is currently in service with various militaries and special forces groups.

A Russian submachine gun based on the AK series rifles with a 64 round helical magazine. It is designed for use by police and counter-terrorist forces who need a compact weapon that can provide a large volume of fire at close ranges.

The PP-91 Kedr, based on the Soviet-era PP-71 prototype from the 1970s, is a selective fire SMG designed by Yevgeny Dragunov. It is blowback operated and fires from a closed bolt, allowing for more accurate shooting than would be possible from an open bolt design. The SMG is chambered for 9x18mm Makarov rounds.
A Belgian personal defense weapon designed as a compact yet poweful weapon for use by special forces and military support personnel. It uses a top mounted magazine and is fully ambidexterous.
A Ukrainian semi-automatic pistol that serves alongside the Makarov PM. It has a larger magazine and more ergonomic features.

A German assault rifle with an integrated 3.0x fixed magnification optic. It uses proprietary magazines and a side folding stock. Although it is quite modern, the rifle has problems with overheating during extended firefights.
A variant of the G36 assault rifle with a shorter overall length and an accessory rail for mounting optics.
A very compact variant of the G36 assault rifle that features a modified flash hider and shorter handguard to more easily maneuver in cramped areas.

An experimental weapon develped by the scientists in the Agroprom Research Institute. Its energy source is fragments of a Flash artifact located inside the magazine. It uses an advanced recoil reduction system reach accuracy unheard of in other man-portable weapons and the extreme velocity of the projectile can penetrate all but the heaviest of armor.

A Russian bullpup assault rifle developed to meet the needs of special operations forces who requested a weapon for close combat couter-insurgency operations in Chechnya. It is based on the AKS-74U rifle but is chambered in the 9x39mm cartridge that improves lethality but reduces magazine capacity.

A Belgian-American semi-automatic pistol that has nearly double the magazine capcity of other pistols manufactured around its introduction in the 1930s. It is very widely used and has been in service with over 50 militaries and many police forces.

A British bullpup assault rifle that evolved from the earlier experimental EM-2 rifle. It was designed to replace the more conventional L1A1 rifle and was based on the American AR-18 rifle. Early versions had serious reliablity problems but the A2 version is a reliable workhorse for the UK Armed Forces.
A variant of the AR-15 platform with new gas system that allows the rifle to use a more compact folding stock. This makes the weapon much more suitable for close quarters combat and indoor fighting.
An American pump action shotgun made to the specifications of the US Military. It features a heatshield around the barrel, a strengthened receiver and a bayonet lug.
An AR-15 series rifle descending from the various carbine length M16s used in the Vietnam War. The M4 variant has a 3-round burst fire mode, adjustable stock and accessory rails.
An AR-15 series rifle descending from the various carbine length M16’s used in the Vietnam War. The M4A1 variant has a fully automatic fire mode, adjustable stock and accessory rails.

An American assault rifle adapted from the civilian AR-15 rifle. The design of the stock and the light cartridge help to reduce recoil during automatic fire. The 5.56x45mm cartridge has a high velocity and fragments inside of targets, causing massive internal wounding. The original M16 rifles have a very poor reputation for reliablity.

An American assault rifle adapted from the civilian AR-15 rifle. The design of the stock and the light cartridge help to reduce recoil during automatic fire. The 5.56x45mm cartridge has a high velocity and fragments inside of targets, causing massive internal wounding. The A1 variant includes a forward assist to aid in clearing jams.

An American assault rifle adapted from the civilian AR-15 rifle. The design of the stock and the light cartridge help to reduce recoil during automatic fire. The 5.56x45mm cartridge has a high velocity and fragments inside of targets, causing massive internal wounding. The A2 variant features new rifling, a new rear sight and a redesigned flash suppressor. The automatic firing mode was replaced with a 3-round burst.

An American assault rifle adapted from the civilian AR-15 rifle. The design of the stock and the light cartridge help to reduce recoil during automatic fire. The 5.56x45mm cartridge has a high velocity and fragments inside of targets, causing massive internal wounding. The A3 variant is essentially an M16A2 with a full automatic fire mode in place of the 3-round burst setting.
For the M16A4 the carrying handle of the M16A2 has been replaced with a picatinny rail system which allows the mounting of different sights.
A variant of the M16A4 rifle with a desert camo pattern and Leupold Mark 4 sight.

The MP-412 REX is a Russian double-action/single-action revolver designed by the state-owned Izhevsk Mechanical Plant (IZHMEKH), with a break-action chamber and an automatic ejector, chambered for the .357 Magnum round. REX stands for “Revolver for EXport.”
A German submachine gun that is in wide use with militaries, law enforcement and counter-terrorist forces. It is based on the larger G3 rifle and has a very similar layout and operating mechanism.
A German submachine gun designed as a cheaper and lighter replacement for the MP5. To accomodate for the larger .45 ACP cartridge, its rate of fire was lowered.
A variant of the MP5 with an integrated suppressor. In order to reduce the sound of firing the suppressor has vents that let gas escape so that the bullet will not produce a supersonic crack.
A Russian submachine gun designed for police and special forces soldiers. It was specifically designed to use armor-piercing 9x19mm cartridges.

A Czechoslovak machine pistol originally developed for use with security forces and special forces. The weapon was also accepted into service with the Czechoslovak Army, as a personal sidearm for lower-ranking army staff, vehicle drivers, armoured vehicle personnel and special forces.
A Russian semi-automatic pistol with an integrated suppressor. It is based on the Makarov PM. The suppressor can be detached and the pistol will still function as normal.

A Russian semi-automatic pistol designed to replace the TT-33 is service among the police and armed forces. The 9x18mm cartridge is somewhat weak compared to other pistol cartridges, but the fixed barrel makes it a quite accurate weapon.
A modernization of the Makarov PM that was developed along with a newer, more powerful 9x18mm cartridge. It has larger 12 round magazine and increased muzzle velocity.

A South African revolving cylinder shotgun designed for riot control and urban combat. It functions similarly to a traditional revolver but with the addition of an automatic shell ejection system to speed up reloading.

An American pump-action shotgun widely used by police, armed forces and civilians for hunting and self-defense. They have a reputation as reliable, inexpensive weapons and have been in continuous production since 1951.

A Russian revolving cylinder grenade launcher designed to increase the firepower of infantry in urban combat. It fires the same caseless VOG-25 grenades as the GP-25. A clockwork style spring must be wound up when reloading the weapon.

A Russian general purpose machine gun. Its operating mechanism resembles an AK-47 that has been turned upside down but it has been changed to an open bolt design which reduces chances of overheating. Most of the openings on the weapon are covered by spring loaded dust covers that make it much harder for debris to clog up the action.

A Russian rocket-propelled grenade launcher known for its simplicity, low cost and effectiveness against armored vehicles, infantry and structures. It has the ability to fire a wide range of warheads varying from anti-tank to bunker clearing thermobaric rockets. It is a common sight in war zones all across the world and a favorite among guerrilla and insurgent groups.

A Swiss-German semi-automatic pistol with a durable steel construction and good accuracy. Although they have mediocre magazine capacity, they are still desireable pistols for their solid construction.

A Swiss-made SGI-5k assault rifle. Although it is hardly new, it is clear that the previous owner took good care of it: the weapon has been taken apart and put back together, with every component fine-tuned for optimum performance, increasing stopping power. The letter “S” has been carved into the stock, along with 16 small notches.

A relatively new assault rifle that has quickly found admirers around the world despite lacking a “trendy” design. Weapons of this series are one of the best in their class, renowned for their reliability, accuracy and ease of use. Despite being relatively difficult to obtain in the Zone, this assault rifle is often ordered by experienced stalkers at considerable expense. The 551 variant is a shorter carbine iteration.

A Swiss assault rifle designed to be modular, accurate and reliable. They are excellent rifles, but pricy and heavier than most other assault rifles. The commando variant has a very short barrel and internal modifications to accomodate for its decreased size.

A Belgian-American battle rifle developed to meet the needs of the United States Special Operations Command. It is modular and lightweight for its size and caliber making it an attractive choice for special forces groups.

A French semi-automatic combat shotgun that can operate in either semi-automatic or pump-action mode depending on the shells being used. Although it starred in many movies and video games, it was not particularly successful due to its complicated internal mechanism and high price. Nevertheless they are very effective at close ranges.

The SR-1M was designed within the “Grach” army program to develop weapons chambered for enhanced 9x21mm Gyurza ammunition. It was rejected by the army, but was immediately picked up by law enforcement agencies such as the FSB as a replacement for the APS pistols.
An American semi-automatic sniper rifle based on the AR-10 and AR-15 rifles. The heavy free-floated barrel increases accuracy at long range for precision sniper work.

A Russian designated marksman rifle designed to increase the combat range of an infantry squad. While externally similar to the AK series, internally it is completely redesigned for improved accuracy. With match-grade 7N14 ammunition it can even rival the accuracy of many bolt-action sniper rifles.

A Russian modification of the SVD Dragunov to make it more suitable for special operations forces. It was lightened, changed to a bullpup configuration and a new muzzle break was added that greatly reduces recoil.
A civilian over-under hunting shotgun that is popular due to its low price and simplicity.
A civilian side-by-side hunting shotgun that is popular due to its low price and simplicity. This example has been cut down to make it more concealable and easier to handle.
A civilian side-by-side hunting shotgun that is popular due to its low price and simplicity.
An unknown weapon, the firing mechanism of which has not been established. The weapon appears faulty - squeezing the trigger doesn’t do anything.

A German semi-automatic pistol based on American pistols such as the M1911 and Browning Hi-Power. It has a heavy recoil spring to reduce the recoil and make follow up shots easier. They are very well built and can function reliably in any environment.

A Russian assault rifle with an integral suppressor. It was developed for quietly engaging armored targets at ranges of less than 300 meters. It is similar to the VSS Vintorez but has plastic furniture and a folding stock.
A Russian assault rifle designed to be very compact and lightweight. It lacks an integral suppressor like the AS VAL or VSS Vintorez but is usually issused with larger magazines

A Russian sniper rifle with an integral suppressor. It was developed for clandestine operations so operators could silently engage targets with body armor without being discovered. It is similar to the AS Val but has and a fixed wooden stock.

The 9mm Gyurza handgun was designed by Peter Serdyukov, working for TsNIITochMash. This handgun is meant for special forces and is designed to penetrate a ballistic vest or the cabin of a car, as well as a radar dish or a hull of a rocket.

A German-made bullpup sniper rifle, developed by Walther GmbH in 1982. Only 176 specimens were made, as they were extremely expensive and not durable enough for military use. Because of their rarity, no one knows how Nimble manages to smuggle these into the Zone.
A German semi-automatic pistol developed for law enforcement and civilian use. It uses an impact resistant polymer frame to reduce weight and has a very ergonomic design.
An American pump-action shotgun designed for the civilian and law enforcement market. They are popular home defense and hunting shotguns.
